''Sports News As It Happens'' (1996–1997) | country = United States | language = English | broadcast area = Nationwide | headquarters = [[Bethpage, New York]] | former names = | replaced names = | replaced by names = American Sports Classics | sister names = [[SportsChannel]] | timeshift names = | web = }} '''NewSport''' is a defunct American [[cable television|cable]] and [[satellite television|satellite]] [[television network]] that was owned by Rainbow Programming Holdings, a [[joint venture]] between the [[Rainbow Media]] subsidiary of [[Cablevision]], [[NBC]] and [[Liberty Media]].{{cite web|title=Ailes cure for CNBC, talk web|url=https://variety.com/1993/scene/news/ailes-cure-for-cnbc-talk-web-110057/|author=John Dempsey|periodical=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=August 31, 1993|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} Predating the launch of the originally similar [[ESPNews]] by three years, it focused on 24-hour coverage of [[sports journalism|sports news]] and analysis. ==History== NewSport debuted on October 1, 1993, replacing [[SportsChannel America]], a national version spun off of Rainbow's SportsChannel [[regional sports network]] group.{{cite news|title=ESPN 2 Ready For Prime Time|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/05/sports/espn-2-ready-for-prime-time.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 5, 1993|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} NewSport developed a unique [[news ticker|sports ticker]], known as the "NewSport Score Box", which debuted in 1995 and provided constantly updated score information on ongoing games and schedules for upcoming sports events at the bottom right of the screen. The network also aired original programs such as ''NewSport Talk'' (a sports discussion program), ''NewSport Journal'', ''NewSport Tonite'' (a nightly program featuring news and analysis on the day in sports) and ''Scoreboard Central'' (which premiered on April 29, 1995, a 12-hour sports news program that aired on Saturdays and Sundays from 12:00 p.m. to 12:00 a.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Time]]).{{cite news|title=NEWSPORT TO LAUNCH NEWS PROGRAM SCOREBOARD CENTRAL|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/1995/04/26/Sports-Media/NEWSPORT-TO-LAUNCH-NEWS-PROGRAM-SCOREBOARD-CENTRAL.aspx?hl=NewSport&sc=0|periodical=Sports Business Journal|date=April 26, 1995|accessdate=April 13, 2015}} The network was slow to grow in coverage, with relatively limited carriage on cable system operators besides Cablevision, owner of SportsChannel and NewSport parent Rainbow Media. Ironically, even Cablevision did not give the network full-time coverage as it carried NewSport on the channel slots also occupied by [[The Weather Channel]] on some of their systems through a time-share arrangement. At its peak, NewSport had only about 10 million subscribers nationwide. This slow growth and lack of viewers, combined with the wide distribution and success of ESPNEWS and Rainbow reportedly losing more than $20 million operating the network, resulted in Rainbow Programming Holdings deciding to shut down NewSport on July 9, 1997.{{cite web|title=NEWSPORT ENDS OPERATION; SUBSCRIBERS GET NEW CLASSIC CHANNEL|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/1997/05/2/Sports-Media/NEWSPORT-ENDS-OPERATION-SUBSCRIBERS-GET-NEW-CLASSIC-CHANNEL.aspx?hl=NewSport&sc=0|periodical=Sports Business Journal|date=May 2, 1997|accessdate=April 12, 2015}} ==American Sports Classics== '''American Sports Classics''' is a network that focused on sports nostalgia programming; it was originally set to launch after NewSport ceased operations on July 9, 1997, however its launch was postponed "indefinitely" for a time, after Rainbow Media transferred control of the network to Fox/Liberty Networks, a joint venture between [[News Corporation]], Liberty Media and Cablevision created after News Corporation acquired a 40% stake in Cablevision's sports properties for $850 million in June 1997.{{cite news|title=SPORTS LANDSCAPE ALTERED WITH FOX/LIBERTY-CABLEVISION DEAL|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/1997/06/23/Sports-Media/SPORTS-LANDSCAPE-ALTERED-WITH-FOXLIBERTY-CABLEVISION-DEAL.aspx?hl=American%20Sports%20Classics&sc=1|periodical=Sports Business Journal|date=June 23, 1997|accessdate=April 13, 2015}} When it launched that fall, the network featured a broad mix of biographical and magazine-style programs. ASC's format contrasted with the similarly focused Classic Sports Network (which later became [[ESPN Classic]]), which at the time mostly showed archived sports event telecasts. Indeed, the reason why the launch was postponed in the first place was due to problems Rainbow faced in trying to obtain the rebroadcast rights to sporting events from the major professional and collegiate sports leagues or their broadcast partners, forcing American Sports Classics to rely on the magazine and biographical programs.{{cite news|title=AMERICAN SPORTS CLASSICS' LAUNCH ON HOLD "INDEFINITELY"|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/1997/07/9/Sports-Media/AMERICAN-SPORTS-CLASSICS-LAUNCH-ON-HOLD-INDEFINITELY.aspx?hl=American%20Sports%20Classics&sc=1|periodical=Sports Business Journal|date=July 9, 1997|accessdate=April 13, 2015}} Like NewSport, ASC was unable to stand up to its competitors, specifically Classic Sports Network. The network ceased operations in mid-1998, shortly after SportsChannel discontinued operations upon its merger with [[Fox Sports Networks|Fox Sports Net]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Sports television in the United States}} {{SportsChannel America}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Newsport}} [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1993]] [[Category:Television channels and stations disestablished in 1997]] [[Category:Defunct American television networks]] [[Category:Sports television networks in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct television stations in the United States]] [[Category:SportsChannel| ]] [[Category:Joint ventures]]

'''Nora Brooks Blakely''' (born September 8, 1951)<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rhynes|first1=Martha E.|title=Gwendolyn Brooks : poet from Chicago|date=2003|publisher=Morgan Reynolds Pub.|location=Greensboro, N.C.|isbn=9781931798051|edition=1st|page=50}}</ref> is a literary editor and agent. {{for|the application on Apple's iOS operating system formerly known as Passbook|Apple Wallet}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} [[File:SampleBankbook.png|200px|right|thumb|Sample passbook (open), containing the same transactions as the [[bank statement]]]] A '''passbook''' or '''bankbook''' is a paper book used to record bank, or [[building society]] transactions on a [[deposit account]].
[[File:Inside a Post Office Savings Bank deposit book.jpg|thumb|right|200px|alt=A page with a pre-printed table. It has handwritten entries showing amounts of deposits and withdrawals, and the balance. Each entry has a post office date stamp.|The [[National Savings and Investments|Post Office Savings Bank]] introduced passbooks to rural 19th century Britain]]
Traditionally, a passbook is used for accounts with a low transaction volume, such as a [[savings account]]. A [[bank teller]] or [[postmaster]] would write, by hand, the date and amount of the transaction, the updated balance, and enter his or her initials. In the late 20th century, small [[dot matrix printer|dot matrix]] or [[inkjet printer]]s were introduced capable of updating the passbook at the account holder's convenience, either at an [[automated teller machine]] or a passbook printer, either in a self-serve mode, by post, or in a [[branch (banking)|branch]].
==History== Passbooks appeared in the 18th century, allowing customers to hold transaction information in their own hands for the first time. Up until then transactions were recorded in ledgers at the bank only, so that customers had no history of their own deposits and withdrawals.
The passbook, which was around the size of a passport, ensured that customers had control over their own information, and was called a "passbook" because it was used as a way to identify the account holder without needing further identification. It also regularly passed between the bank and the account holder for updating.<ref name=telegraphpass>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/savings/9326252/Back-to-the-future-savings-passbook-trumps-the-internet.html |title=Back to the future' savings passbook trumps the internet |date=June 12, 2012 |publisher=The Telegraph}}</ref>
==Usage== ===Credits and deposits=== To add credit to an account by bringing [[cash]] to a bank in person, the account holder can fill a small '''''credit slip''''' or '''''deposit slip'''''. The total amount of each note and coin is counted and entered on the slip, along with who it is paid in by and the date. The cash and details are counted and checked by the teller at the bank, if everything is in order the deposit is credited to the account, the ''credit slip'' is then kept by the bank and the ''credit slip booklet'' is stamped with the date and then returned to the account holder. An account holder uses their passbook to record their history of transactions with their bank.
===Debits and withdrawals=== Withdrawals normally required the account holder to visit the branch where the account was held, where a '''''debit slip''''' or '''''withdrawal slip''''' would be prepared and signed. If the account holder was not known to the teller, the signature on the slip and the authorities would be checked against the signature card at the branch, before money was paid out. In the 1980s, banks adopted the black light signature system for passbooks, which enabled withdrawals to be made from passbooks at a branch other than the one where an account was opened, unless prior arrangements were made to transfer the signature card to the other branch. Under this system, the passbook's owner would sign in the back of the passbook in an invisible ink and the signing authorities would also be noted. At the paying branch, the signature on the withdrawal slip would be checked against the signature in the book, which required a special ultraviolet reader to read.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aso.gov.au/titles/sponsored-films/commonwealth-bank-school-bank/clip2/ |title=Commonwealth Bank – The School Bank (1951) |date= |author= |publisher=Australia Screen |accessdate=23 December 2012 }}</ref> Nowadays, customer verification is more likely to be by [[Personal identification number|PIN]] and commonly from an [[automated teller machine]].
==Direct banking== {{Main|Direct bank}} For people who feel uneasy with [[telephone banking|telephone]] or [[online banking]], the use of a passbook is an alternative to obtain, in real-time, the account activity without waiting for a [[bank statement]]. However, contrary to some bank statements, some passbooks offer fewer details, replacing easy-to-understand descriptions with short codes.<ref name=telegraphpass></ref>
==Gallery of passbooks== <gallery caption="Passbook gallery"> File:Saffron Building Society Passbook.jpg|[[Saffron Building Society]] passbook File:Leeds Building Society Passbook.jpg|[[Leeds Building Society]] passbook File:Nottingham Building Society Passbook.jpg|[[Nottingham Building Society]] passbook File:Postsparbuch Vorderseite 1984.jpg|German Postsparbuch, cover File:Sparbuch der Deutschen Bundespost 1986, Doppelseite.jpg|German Postsparbuch
</gallery>

{{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = Peter Colwell Bawden | honorific-suffix = | image = Peter Bawden.jpg | image_size = 200px | constituency_MP = [[Calgary South]] | parliament = Canadian | predecessor = [[Patrick Morgan Mahoney]] | successor = [[John William Thomson]] | term_start = 1972 | term_end = 1979 | birth_date = {{birth date|1929|1|1}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | death_date = {{death date and age|1991|2|28|1929|1|1}} | death_place = [[Calgary, Alberta]], Canada | nationality = Canadian | spouse = | party = [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative]] | relations = | children = [[Jennifer Bawden]] | residence = | alma_mater = [[Upper Canada College]] | occupation = businessman, federal politician | profession = oil executive | religion = }} '''Peter Colwell Bawden''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|OC}} (January 1, 1929 – February 28, 1991) was a prominent [[Canadians|Canadian]] oilman, cabinet minister, former Member of Parliament and in 1990 was appointed as an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]].<ref>Source: Calgary Herald, March 1991</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gg.ca/honour.aspx?id=2595&t=12&ln=bawden&lan=eng|title=The Governor General of Canada (Public Release)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Bawden was elected to the [[House of Commons of Canada]] representing the riding of [[Calgary South]], the heart of Canada’s oil industry. A [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative]], he was re-elected in [[Canadian federal election, 1974|1974]].
== Oil and gas exploration == [[File:Bawden Drilling Oil Rig-1.jpg|thumb|left|One of the first Bawden Drilling oil rigs in Calgary, Canada; circa 1955.]][[File:Bawden Drilling Oil Rig-2 Gas Flaring.jpg|thumb|left|A Bawden Drilling North Sea oil rig; circa 1980.]][[File:King Hussein of Jordan & Peter Bawden.jpg|thumb|King Hussein of Jordan & Peter Bawden. King Hussein hosted Peter Bawden in 1979 as an official guest of the Country of Jordan.]][[File:Bawden Drilling Houston Office--500px.png|thumb|Bawden Drilling United States headquarters in Houston, Texas.]] Bawden founded and built the world’s largest (at the time) privately owned oil and gas drilling company. In business for over 35 years, and consisting of a large fleet of offshore and land rigs operated from offices worldwide, Bawden Drilling worked closely with Shell Oil, Mobil Corporation and Dome Petroleum, among others.<ref>Nielsen, A. (2015). We gambled everything: The life and times of an oilman.</ref>
He moved to Alberta in the fall of 1950 and founded Peter Bawden Drilling in 1952 shortly after his arrival in Calgary. In 1960, at the age of 31, Peter Bawden’s first drilling rig struck oil. With its acquisition of Trident Drilling, Bawden Drilling became Canada’s largest drilling company. In 1968, Peter Bawden Drilling acquired Brown Drilling in California. Thereafter, as a land drilling contractor, Bawden expanded the company's on-shore operations throughout North America, from the Arctic to the Gulf of Mexico, to Norway, Algeria, Australia, New Guinea, Indonesia, Philippines, Guatemala, Venezuela, Colombia, Madagascar, and the Middle East. Eventually having operations on every continent in the world.
A notable contribution of the Bawden organization was the development of Canadian oilfield expertise and technology in many parts of the world. Bawden’s first offshore assignments began in 1968 off the coast of Australia where the company operated that continent’s first self-containing platform rigs. In the North Sea, Bawden Drilling became the largest development-drilling contractor in the United Kingdom. Well known for technological, industry advances, Bawden designed and built the world’s largest (at that time) semi-submersible rig for Shell Oil. They also had large platform rig operations off the California coast, in the Persian Gulf and off the coast of Malaysia.
Bawden set many industry records including drilling a deviated well -11,324 feet in eighteen days from a fixed platform in the North Sea. Other notable rigs were located in the middle of the Pasadena Raceway and behind the Beverly Hills high school. He was a visionary trailblazer in his 1964 activities to promote Canada as an exporter of LNG (Liquefied Petroleum Gases). In 1977, he created Mosswood Oil & Gas expanding into oil production.
Peter Bawden committed his life to the search for oil, gas and geothermal energy. Geothermal Drilling was a Bawden specialty with over 20 years of experience in the challenging tapping of hot water and steam reservoirs. Bawden won numerous industry awards for its emphasis on safety. The company also received the Canadian Export Award in 1985 and Export Achievement Awards in the years 1981, 1983, 1984, 1985 and 1986.
== Canadian Parliament and public service == [[File:Canadian Prime Minister Joe Clark and Minister of Parliament Peter Bawden.jpg|alt=Canadian Prime Minister Joe Clark and Minister of Parliament Peter Bawden (circa 1980)|left|thumb|Canadian Prime Minister Joe Clark and Minister of Parliament Peter Bawden (circa 1980)]] Bawden was honored in 1990 as an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]] for being "largely responsible for pioneering oil and gas drilling in the Arctic Circle and for the international transfer of Canadian expertise and technology in this field".<ref>[http://www.gg.ca/honour.aspx?id=2595&t=12&ln=Bawden Governor General of Canada]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.canadianpetroleumhalloffame.ca/peter-bawden.html|title=Peter C. Bawden (1929–1991) 2010 Inductee - Canadian Petroleum Hall of Fame|website=www.canadianpetroleumhalloffame.ca|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref><ref>Cameron, A. B. (1999). ''Under sand, ice & sea: The memoirs of an oilman''. Toronto: Erracht Pub.</ref> Peter Bawden was the first drilling contractor to drill in the Canadian Arctic where the harsh and remote environment demanded special logistical planning. He is recognized for the first offshore crude oil discovery in Canadian history on Sable Island earning the cover story of Mobil Corporation's magazine in 1971.
[[File:Canadian Prime Minister Diefenbaker & Peter Bawden, Canadian Minister of Parliament.jpg|alt=In 1972, with the strong endorsement of former Prime Minister Diefenbaker, Peter Bawden won the liberal stronghold, Calgary South, with one of the biggest landslides in the country.|left|thumb|In 1972, with the strong endorsement of Prime Minister Diefenbaker, Peter Bawden won the liberal stronghold, Calgary South, with one of the biggest landslides in the country.]] Bawden had a distinguished public service career and was elected (with one of the biggest majorities in the country) as a Member of the Canadian House of Commons in 1972 and re-elected in 1974. During his years in Ottawa he served on the Commons Committee on Finance, Natural Resources, Trade and Economic Affairs, including External Affairs and National Defense. For seven years he served as a delegate to the NATO Parliamentary Assembly representing the Canadian Parliament to meet and discuss common security problems. He also served on the Canada/US Inter-parliamentary Committee.
His community service included acting as a Director in the Business Council of National Issues, Calgary Special Olympics and Trustee of the Canadian Olympic Association and Wycliffe College in Toronto. His membership included Canada West Foundation, Ducks Unlimited Canada, and he was an Honorary Colonel of the 14th (Calgary) Service Battalion, Honorary Vice-President of the Calgary Regional Council of the Boy Scouts of Canada and Director of the Confederation of Church and Business People, and he was the founding donor to [http://www.calgaryfoundation.org/ The Calgary Foundation].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://calgary-foundation.s3.amazonaws.com/mercury_assets/1094/original.pdf?1443104431|title=Calgary Foundation Annual Report (2014-2015)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>[[File:Bawden Drilling World Map.png|thumb|Bawden Drilling Global Oil & Gas Operations|225x225px]][[File:Bawden Drilling Crew.jpg|thumb|Bawden Drilling crew conducting safety training circa 1979.]]
== Other companies == Peter Bawden served as a director on a number of prestigious Canadian companies including Barclays Bank, Air Canada, Boeing, Safeway, Procor Limited, Jannock Ltd, Westair Resources Ltd and Mosswood Oil & Gas Ltd. He was a member of the Business Council on National Issues, the World Business Council and the Washington Quarterly Roundtable.
=== Aviation === A pilot at age 17, Bawden also made a substantial contribution to the aviation industry and founded in 1991, Executive Flight Centre, Canada's largest aviation service company, including a large fleet of planes and jets.
== Personal life == [[File:Jen on Bawden Drilling Oil Rig--fixed.jpg|left|thumb| Jennifer Bawden, daughter of Peter Bawden (founder of Bawden Drilling Company) visiting one of the company's oil rigs in Jakarta, Indonesia.]]
=== Childhood === Born into the Toronto establishment, Peter Bawden attended Upper Canada College in Toronto. He was the son of Harry Norman Bawden, who was President, CEO and later Vice Chairman of Dominion Securities, one of Canada’s largest investment banks before it was acquired by the Royal Bank of Canada in 1996.
Harry Bawden was Director of the War Finance Committee; a board member of Molson's Brewery; a board member of Dominion Foundries & Steel, among others.
=== Chuck wagon racing === During the late 1950s and 1960s the Peter Bawden chuck wagon dominated the World Chuck Wagon Races at the Calgary Stampede and broke several world track records.{{clear}}

{{use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Pinhas "Pini" Zahavi | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|08|24}} | birth_place = [[Ness Ziona]], Israel | nationality = Israeli, Polish | occupation = [[Sports agent]] }} '''Pinhas''' "'''Pini'''" '''Zahavi''' ({{lang-he-n|פנחס "פיני" זהבי}}; born 24 August 1943<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi">Jackson, Jamie. [https://web.archive.org/web/20160124074112/http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2006/nov/26/football.features "Profile: Pini Zahavi, football's first and only super-agent"], [[The Observer]], 26 November 2005. Retrieved 2007-07-12</ref>) is an Israeli [[association football|football]] [[sports agent|agent]].
Zahavi is known for his involvement in the change of ownership of [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]]<ref name="'Mr Fix-it' trusted by top clubs' executives">Hunter, Andy. [https://web.archive.org/web/20100906205820/http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/mr-fixit-trusted-by-top-clubs-executives-453308.html "'Mr Fix-it' trusted by top clubs' executives"], [[The Independent]] 16 June 2007. Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref> and for his work as a football agent, especially the (at the time) record-breaking transfer of [[Rio Ferdinand]].
Zahavi is licensed as a football [[sports agent|agent]] from his offices in [[Tel Aviv]] through the [[Israel Football Association]].<ref>[https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/federation/administration/playersagents/association=isr.html "Pini Zahavi registration"], [[FIFA]]. Accessed 2010-07-28</ref>
==Early life and career in journalism== Zahavi was born in [[Ness Ziona]] in 1943, the son of a shopkeeper who sold building materials to local tradesmen. He has two elder sisters and a brother.<ref name="From journalist to sports Svengali">Wilson, Jonathan. [https://web.archive.org/web/20080604180332/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7d18fc5a-1ba6-11dc-bc55-000b5df10621.html "From journalist to sports Svengali"], [[The Financial Times]] 16 June 2007. Retrieved 2010-07-27</ref> <ref name="The Man Selling Rio">Bond, David. [https://web.archive.org/web/20121012112949/http://www.standard.co.uk/sport/the-man-selling-rio-6316990.html "The Man Selling Rio"], [[The Evening Standard]] 19 July 2002. Retrieved 2010-07-27</ref>
Zahavi began a career as a football journalist after dropping out of university.<ref name="The go-between who oils wheels for Abramovich">Bower, Tom. [http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+go-between+who+oils+wheels+for+Abramovich%3b+CHELSEA+REVOLUTION.-a0107736671 "The go-between who oils wheels for Abramovich"], [[The Daily Mail]] 13 September 2003. Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref> He worked for the Israeli newspapers ''Hadashot Hasport'', ''[[Yedioth Ahronoth]]'' and ''[[Hadashot]]''.<ref name="From journalist to sports Svengali"/>
Zahavi negotiated his first deal in 1979, the transfer of Israeli defender [[Avi Cohen]] from [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. As a sports journalist, he built up a network of contacts throughout the 1980s. He gave up his job as a journalist in 1998 and negotiated his second deal the following year. This marked the beginning of his career as an agent and he continued to develop close ties in the football world by organising friendly internationals in Israel, inviting players, including [[Graeme Souness]] and [[Kenny Dalglish]], to holiday at his villa in [[Eilat]],<ref name="From journalist to sports Svengali"/> and even taking oranges to Melwood, Liverpool's training ground, as a gift for players and staff.<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi"/>
==Career as an agent==
===First transfer dealings=== Zahavi's first transfer deal was undertaken in 1979 when he helped arrange the transfer of Israeli defender Avi Cohen from Maccabi Tel Aviv to Liverpool for £200,000.<ref name="From journalist to sports Svengali"/> Zahavi, who traveled to England regularly to watch football, recommended Cohen to Liverpool when he saw Peter Robinson, the then secretary of the club, at [[Heathrow]] airport during a flight delay caused by fog.<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi"/> The player had got to know Zahavi through his coverage of Maccabi Tel Aviv in ''Yedioth Ahronoth''.<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi"/> Zahavi was paid an introduction fee for his part in the deal.<ref name="The go-between who oils wheels for Abramovich"/>
A year later, Zahavi arranged a loan move to Maccabi Tel Aviv for [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] player [[Barry Silkman]], with whom Zahavi would later be associated with when Silkman became a football [[sports agent|agent]].<ref name="How Zahavi made contact sport an art form and became English football's kingmaker">Conn, David. [https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/jan/17/sport.comment1 "How Zahavi made contact sport an art form and became English football's kingmaker"], [[The Guardian]] 17 January 2007. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref>
In 1990, Zahavi negotiated the transfer of another Israeli player, forward [[Ronnie Rosenthal]], from [[Standard Liège]] to Liverpool.<ref name="From journalist to sports Svengali"/> [[Kenny Dalglish]] was by then Liverpool's manager.<ref name="From journalist to sports Svengali"/>
===Rio Ferdinand=== By this time, Zahavi had built an extensive network of contacts within English football. His friendships included not just [[Graeme Souness]] and Dalglish, but also [[Terry Venables]], [[Ron Atkinson]] and [[Alex Ferguson]], as well as many more among the next generation of managers and players.
In 1997, Zahavi negotiated the transfer of Israeli midfielder [[Eyal Berkovic]] from [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] to [[West Ham United]].<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi"/> Zahavi's association with Berkovic had already been responsible for the player's move from [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] to English football at Southampton, then being managed by Zahavi's friend, Graeme Souness.<ref name="Pini plots world domination">Bond, David, Northcroft, Jonathan and Hawkey, Ian. "Pini plots world domination", [[The Sunday Times]], 13 July 2003. [http://find.galegroup.com/gps/infomark.do?&contentSet=IAC-Documents&type=retrieve&tabID=T004&prodId=IPS&docId=CJ105424543&source=gale&srcprod=SP00&userGroupName=suf_earl&version=1.0 Link to article on InfoTrac National Newspapers Database (login required)]. Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref>
A side effect of the West Ham deal was that it was brought Zahavi into contact with [[Rio Ferdinand]]. Zahavi handled the transfer that took Ferdinand from West Ham to [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] for £18 million in 2000,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/1035797.stm "Leeds ready for place among elite"], [[BBC]], 22 November 2000. Retrieved 2010-07-27</ref> and then his £30 million transfer from Leeds to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in 2002. As part of the deal, Zahavi was himself paid £1.13 million.<ref name="Why transfers and transparency still do not mix">Conn, David. [https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2009/feb/04/david-conn-transfer-window-player-agent-fees "Why transfers and transparency still do not mix"], [[The Guardian]] 4 February 2009. Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref>
Zahavi was a friend of the Manchester United manager Alex Ferguson, whom he had first got to know in the late 1980s, and by the time of the Ferdinand transfer he was responsible for brokering almost every major Manchester United deal, including the sale of [[Jaap Stam]] to [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] for £16.5 million and the purchase of [[Juan Sebastián Verón]] from the same club for £28.1 million in 2001. [[Juan Sebastián Verón]] had been signed for Lazio by another friend of Zahavi's, [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]], whom he knew first as a young coach at [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]].<ref name="Pini plots world domination"/>
===Roman Abramovich and Chelsea=== In 2003, Zahavi played an important and central role in [[Roman Abramovich]]'s acquisition of [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and to the influx of players that followed.<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi"/> Zahavi became an influential member of Abramovich's inner circle<ref name="'Mr Fix-it' trusted by top clubs' executives"/> and was estimated to have earned as much as £5 million from the £111 million that Chelsea spent on players that summer.<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi"/>
In 1998, Zahavi had been introduced to Abramovich in [[Moscow]] by a mutual friend and so was able to provide an introduction when he was approached by Trevor Birch, the chief executive of the heavily indebted Chelsea, who were on the verge of being unable to pay their players' wages.<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi"/><ref name="One Oligarch's story">Belash, Vyacheslav. [http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?idr=1&id=522955 "One Oligarch's story"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012105950/http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?idr=1&id=522955# |date=12 October 2012 }}, [[Kommersant]] 11 November 2004. Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref><ref name="Zahavi: from humble beginnings to multimillionaire power broker">Broadbent, Rick. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article1940568.ece "Zahavi: from humble beginnings to multimillionaire power broker"], [[The Times]] 16 June 2007. Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref> Abramovich had previously considered purchasing Manchester United and then [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref name="How soccer's Mr Fixit brokered the deal between Chelsea and billionaire oil man">Curry, Steve. "How soccer's Mr Fixit brokered the deal between Chelsea and billionaire oil man", [[The Daily Mail]], 3 July 2003. [http://find.galegroup.com/gps/infomark.do?&contentSet=IAC-Documents&type=retrieve&tabID=T004&prodId=IPS&docId=CJ104655454&source=gale&srcprod=SP00&userGroupName=suf_earl&version=1.0 Link to article on InfoTrac National Newspapers Database (login required).] Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref>
==="Tapping-up" controversies=== ====Ashley Cole==== In 2005, [[The Football Association]] (FA) recommended that Zahavi be investigated by the responsible bodies for his part in the "tapping-up" of the [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] left back [[Ashley Cole]], who was approached by Chelsea in contravention of [[Premier League]] regulations.<ref name="The full judgement on Cole affair">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4601247.stm "The full judgement on Cole affair"], [[BBC]] 1 June 2005. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref>
The independent commission established by the Premier League to investigate the incident after an official complaint by Arsenal concluded that Zahavi and Cole's agent [[Jonathan Barnett (sports agent)|Jonathan Barnett]] had extended an invitation to Chelsea to which the club had responded.<ref name="The full judgement on Cole affair"/> Zahavi and Barnett were then present at the Royal Park Hotel, [[London]], on 27 January 2005 when Cole met the Chelsea manager, [[José Mourinho]], and club's chief executive, [[Peter Kenyon]].<ref name="Cole's agent handed FA suspension">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/5382332.stm "Cole's agent handed FA suspension"], [[BBC]] 26 September 2006. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref>
Chelsea, Mourinho and Cole were all fined for their part in the affair, while Barnett was fined £100,000 and had his licence suspended by the FA for 18 months, later reduced to a 12-month ban.<ref name="Cole's agent handed FA suspension"/><ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=394279&cc=3436 "Cole's agent Barnett loses ban appeal"], [[ESPN]], 1 December 2006. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref> Neither the FA nor the Premier League had any jurisdiction over Zahavi<ref name="Barnett Decision">[http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/Disciplinary/NewsAndFeatures/2006/BarnettDecision "Barnett Decision"], [[The Football Association|F.A.]], 26 September 2006. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref> but referred the matter to [[FIFA]], whose investigation was, as of October 2009, ongoing.<ref name="Carry on investigating at Fifa">Scott, Matt. [https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/oct/13/fifa-pini-zahavi-ashley-cole "Carry on investigating at Fifa"], [[The Guardian]] 13 October 2009. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref> Zahavi maintained his innocence of any wrongdoing, claiming that "at that time I did not represent Chelsea or Ashley Cole".<ref>Bond, David. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2346819/Fifa-closing-in-on-Zahavi.html "Fifa closing in on Zahavi"], [[Daily Telegraph]] 26 September 2006. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref>
====Rio Ferdinand==== In April 2005, Zahavi denied that Chelsea had been engaged in an illegal approach to the Manchester United player Rio Ferdinand when it emerged<ref>Brough, Graham and Lewis, Darren. [http://www.thefreelibrary.com/RIO+%26+THE+CHELSEA+CHIEF%3A+THE+HEAD+HUNTERS%3B+Tapping+up+fear+No2+as...-a0131418726 "Rio & The Chelsea Chief: The Head Hunters; Tapping up fear No2 as United's Ferdinand is spotted in dramatic meeting at restaurant"], [[Daily Mirror]] 13 April 2005. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref> that the defender had met Zahavi and Chelsea's chief executive Peter Kenyon at Carpaccio, a restaurant in [[Chelsea, London]], meeting again at the Elysee Greek eatery near [[Tottenham Court Road]] hours later. Chelsea denied any approach had been made, although then-Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson accused former Manchester United executive Kenyon of treating his former club with "contempt". Zahavi denied that the meetings were an attempt to pressure Manchester United into improving their offered contract to Ferdinand.<ref>Jason Burt. [https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/two-meetings-but-ferdinand-is-innocent-says-his-agent-494860.html "Two meetings but Ferdinand is innocent, says his agent"], [[The Independent]] 19 April 2005. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref>
===Portsmouth=== ====Beginning of association and Yakubu transfer==== Zahavi became associated with [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] under the ownership of [[Milan Mandarić]]. He worked on the signings of Eyal Berkovic and [[Yakubu (footballer)|Yakubu]] from Maccabi Haifa, owned by Zahavi's school friend [[Ya'akov Shahar]], in April 2003 and was involved in the recruitment of [[Collins Mbesuma]] in August 2005.<ref name="How Zahavi made contact sport an art form and became English football's kingmaker"/><ref name="agent with his finger in many Portsmouth pies">Conn, David. [https://www.theguardian.com/football/david-conn-inside-sport-blog/2012/mar/20/pini-zahavi-portsmouth "Pini Zahavi, the agent with his finger in many Portsmouth pies"], [[The Guardian]] 30 March 2012. Retrieved 2012-11-1.</ref>
In July 2005, Zahavi agreed a fee of £3.64 million for his part in Yakubu's transfer from Portsmouth to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]. The fee, agreed with middlesbrough's chief executive Keith Lamb, was to be paid in ten installments over five years if Yakubu remained at the club. The amount was the largest agent fee disclosed in English football at that time and was regarded as being extraordinary.<ref name="£3m - Zahavi's fee for taking Yakubu to Boro">Conn, David. [https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/jan/17/newsstory.sport11 "£3m - Zahavi's fee for taking Yakubu to Boro"], [[The Guardian]] 17 January 2007. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-430239/Footballs-gone-mad-agent-earn-3m-deal.html "Football's gone mad when an agent can earn £3m in one deal"], [[The Daily Mail]] 20 January 2007. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref>
As part of the deal, Zahavi made payments to Barry Silkman, the agent who is understood to have spotted Yakubu's potential when he was playing in Nigeria and to have been responsible for the $500,000 transfer that took the player to Maccabi Haifa in 1999.<ref name="How Zahavi made contact sport an art form and became English football's kingmaker"/>
====Takeover by Alexandre Gaydamak==== In January 2006, Zahavi, together with his partner, assisted with the sale of Portsmouth to [[Alexandre Gaydamak]].<ref name="Gaydamak masters the game with no rules">Conn, David. [https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/jan/11/newsstory.sport1 "Gaydamak masters the game with no rules"], [[The Guardian]] 11 January 2006. Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref> Earlier in his career, Zahavi had assisted with the sale of [[Beitar Jerusalem F.C.|Beitar Jerusalem]] to Gaydamak's father, the Russian–Israeli businessman [[Arkady Gaydamak]].<ref name="Zahavi: from humble beginnings to multimillionaire power broker"/><ref name="agent with his finger in many Portsmouth pies"/>
Zahavi worked on a number of deals for Portsmouth's new regime, bringing [[Avram Grant]] to the club, initially as a technical director in June 2006, signing a two-year scouting contract worth £800,000, and being involved in signing and selling a number of players.
When Portsmouth went into administration after multiple changes of owner in February 2010, Zahavi was among the 24 agents to whom the club owed almost £9 million. His own share of the outstanding amount totalled £2.074 million.<ref name="agent with his finger in many Portsmouth pies"/>
==Other business interests== With his friend and associate, the businessman [[Eli Azur]], Zahavi co-owns a media company, Charlton, that holds the television rights in Israel for major sports, including those of the English Premier League and the [[Israeli Premier League|top flight of Israel's domestic football]].<ref name="Pini plots world domination"/> The decision of the company to broadcast the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] through a pay-per-view offering proved very unpopular in Israel, leading to a boycott of the service and compromising Zahavi's reputation in the country.<ref>Shaul Adar. [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/jun/06/broadcasting.worldcup2006 "Zahavi suffering as Israel boycotts pay-per-view World Cup channel"], [[The Guardian]], 6 June 2006. Retrieved 2010-07-28.</ref>
Zahavi is also holds actions of HAZ Racing Team, one of the top motorsport teams in Argentina (the "Z" on HAZ comes from his last name).
==Personal life== Zahavi is a widower with two children. He lives modestly in a seaside apartment in the north of [[Tel Aviv]] and rents a flat in [[Marble Arch]], London.<ref name="Profile: Pini Zahavi"/> He is the great uncle of footballer [[Alex Zahavi]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox court case | name = Re Taylor | court = [[High Court of New Zealand|Auckland High Court]] | date_filed = | image = Coat of arms of New Zealand.svg | date decided = 1 September 1992 | full name = In Re Taylor | citations = (1992) 4 NZBLC 102,875 | judges = [[Ted Thomas (judge)|Thomas J]] | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = | transcripts = | Keywords = [[Insolvency]], [[Rogernomics]] }} '''''Re Taylor''''' is a leading [[New Zealand]] case on when the [[High Court of New Zealand|High Court]] will exercise its discretion and refuse to adjudicate a debtor [[Bankruptcy|bankrupt]]. ==Background== The background to the application to adjudicate Mr Taylor bankrupt was summarised by [[Ted Thomas (judge)|Justice Thomas]],
Mr Taylor's creditors, Mr and Mrs Greenwood, obtained a summary judgment against Mr Taylor on 17 April 1991 for $21,448.86. The [[summary judgment]] application had not been opposed. The judgment sum represented unpaid rent and outgoings for which Mr Taylor and his wife were liable under a lease which they had taken from Mr and Mrs Greenwood. The lease related to business premises occupied by Mr and Mrs Taylor's company. Sensitive readers liable to be easily disturbed should look the other way when I recite that the company went by the awful name of "Bath and Dunny Shop Limited". As befits its name it went down the drain, and it is now in liquidation.
Following judgment, Mr and Mrs Greenwood were unable to obtain repayment of any part of their [[Judgment (law)|judgment]] debt. They sought execution against Mr and Mrs Taylor's assets, including their [[real property]], but the assets and property proved worthless, and there was no equity available for them or any other unsecured creditors. Consequently, on 16 March last, Mr and Mrs Greenwood issued a bankruptcy notice against Mr Taylor. It was renewed on 16 April 1992 and was finally served on Mr Taylor on 16 May.''Re Taylor'' (1992) 4 NZBLC 102,875.
==Judgment== The debtor, Mr Taylor, made an application in opposition to a [[bankruptcy]] notice. Although Taylor had no [[Legal technicality|technical]] grounds on which to oppose the notice, [[Ted Thomas (judge)|Justice Thomas]] held,
For my part, I consider that adjudicating a person bankrupt when that person is essentially a victim of the current downturn in this country’s economy may, in certain circumstances, be unnecessarily severe. In Mr Taylor’s case I believe that the collapse of his business can be directly traced to the [[Rogernomics|political and economic developments]] which took place at the time. But for those developments, Mr and Mrs Taylor would probably have a thriving business today. Bankruptcy will not now realise one cent in the dollar for Mr and Mrs Greenwood. Moreover it is difficult to perceive any [[public interest]] element which would be served by making Mr Taylor bankrupt. He cannot get a job and it is unlikely that he will get credit. To make Mr Taylor bankrupt would be purely punitive and serve no practical or useful purpose. To my mind, sufficient cause exists for no order of adjudication to be made.
The only question, therefore, is whether the issue of bankruptcy should be left to be finally decided at the hearing of the petition, should Mr and Mrs Greenwood decide to pursue that course, or whether I should [[Stay of proceedings|stay the proceeding]] now. There is much merit in Mr Sadler’s observation that this proceeding should be brought to an end one way or another today. I therefore propose to grant a stay. In the event that Mr and Mrs Greenwood obtain evidence that Mr and Mrs Taylor’s fortunes have changed for the better it would be open to them to apply to the Court to uplift this stay. The debt as Mr and Mrs Taylor will appreciate, remains due and owing.''Re Taylor'' (1992) 4 NZBLC 102,875 at 879.
==Significance== The rule in ''Re Taylor'' is codified in the Insolvency Act 2006 which states that a court may at its discretion refuse to adjudicate a [[debtor]] bankrupt if "it is just and equitable that the court does not make an order of adjudication".Insolvency Act, s 37(c). ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Re Taylor}} [[Category:1992 in New Zealand law]] [[Category:1992 in case law]] [[Category:Insolvency]] [[Category:High Court of New Zealand cases]]

'''Robert Hermann Garbe ''' (pronounced 'Garber') (9 January 1847 – 23 May 1932) was a German railway engineer and chief engineer of the [[Berlin]] division in the [[Prussian state railways]] from 1895 to 1917. He was especially known for his [[steam locomotive]] designs<ref>{{Herring-Ultimate Train}}, 150.</ref> and is described as one of the greatest authorities on the locomotive.<ref>{{Ransome-Wallis Encyclopedia}}, 498.</ref> He was the first to suggest the use of [[superheated steam]], universally. However, he saw superheated steam as competing with other innovations such as double expansion [[compound steam engine]]s (he held a grudge against Hannver's [[August von Borries|August Borries]] that his pupil [[Richard Paul Wagner]] inherited) or [[combustion chamber]]s.
His designs were, on the one hand, simple to maintain and operate; on the other hand, he blocked innovations that every other pre-Reichsbahn state railway used successfully. He held the belief that two coupled axles were enough for any express engine (his masterpiece being the [[Prussian S 6]] class) and trailing axles as in the "Pacific" configuration were unnecessary. The [[Prussian P 8]] class had to be re-designed almost entirely from his design to become successful, and he envisaged it as an express engine.
In that way, he is known as one of the key pioneers of locomotive design because of his achievements concerning the use of superheated steam; his image is tarnished, however, by a conservatism that was proven wrong time and again contemporarily (eg by the [[Bavarian S 3/6]]) and thereafter [[André Chapelon]] designed highly-successful modern compound locomotives, proving the success of every single innovation Garbe rejected).
== Childhood and Education == Born in [[Opole|Oppeln]] (present-day Opole, [[Opole Voivodeship]]), in [[Prussia]]n [[Upper Silesia]] on 9 January 1847, Garbe was the eldest son of the master [[locksmith]], Ferdinand Garbe. He went to elementary school in Oppeln and learned his father's locksmith trade. The desire for further education led him to the technical school at [[Breslau]], where he worked in the main workshops of the Upper Silesian Railway and passed his exams as an engine driver in 1867. He also visited the provincial trade school in [[Brzeg|Brieg]], passed the leaving exams with distinction and went, in 1869, to the Royal Prussian Trade Academy in Berlin (later the Berlin-Charlottenburg Technical High School and, today, the [[Berlin Technical University]]). He finished his studies in 1872 with top marks in all disciplines.
==Prussian Railway Division == Afterwards, Garbe was the director of the Central Railway Workshop in [[Frankfurt (Oder)]]. In 1877 the Ministry entrusted him with leading the main workshop in Berlin-[[Rummelsburg]]. In 1895 Garbe was nominated simultaneously as a board member of the Prussian Railway Division at Berlin and Head of Department for the Design and Procurement of Locomotives. In this capacity he also chaired the locomotive committee that had to make recommendations about future locomotive procurement to the Ministry of Public Works.
In 1907 the Prussian Railway Central Office was founded in Berlin. Here, Garbe took over the sphere of "Construction of Superheated Steam Locomotives and Tenders". Inspired by the work of [[Wilhelm Schmidt (engineer)|Wilhelm Schmidt]] ('Hot Steam Schmidt') from [[Kassel]], Garbe was already in 1893 of the view that the use of [[superheated steam]] would give steam locomotives a power advantage.
== Locomotive Development == The locomotives developed on the basis of the policy issued by Garbe were characterised above all by good performance and simple construction. Consciously, he did not strive for high performance with his designs, but gave priority to reliability and ease of maintenance. By the time Garbe retired, a total of 13 superheated steam locomotive classes had been developed along those lines for all the important locomotive duties, together with a number of experimental designs. Garbe's design fundamentals had been so much part of Prussian locomotive development that they continued to be used even after his retirement.
The [[Prussian P 8]] symbolises to a great extent Garbe's design principles. A total of 3,948 examples were built (including the Rumanian copies) and they were working German railway routes until the end of the steam era around 1972-1974.
Garbe's major achievement in the field of technical steam locomotive development was the introduction of [[superheating]], for which he was a keen advocate.<ref>{{Herring-Ultimate Train}}, 150</ref> He disapproved of [[compound locomotive|compound working]]; he saw superheating as a total replacement for complicated and maintenance-intensive compound systems, not as an enhancement of them to produce increased power.
The most significant acknowledgement was granted to Garbe after he left the service of the state. The Berlin-Charlottenburg Technical High School awarded him an Honorary Doctorate of Engineering for his services in developing the superheated steam locomotive.
He died on 23 May 1932 in [[Berlin]].

(1924) 1981 im Steiger-Verlag in Moers als Reprint. * Maedel/Gottwald: ''Deutsche Dampflokomotiven - Die Entwicklungsgeschichte'' 1999 im Transpress-Verlag.

'''Karl Rudolf Walden''' (December 1, 1878 in [[Helsinki]] – October 25, 1946) was a [[Finland|Finnish]] industrialist and a military leader.
==Education== Walden received his military education at the [[Hamina Cadet School]] and graduated in 1900. He was dismissed from service in 1902, in connection with a conscription strike.
==Finnish civil war== From 20 February 1918, till 5 March 1918, Walden was chief of [[Vaasa]] military district. From then till 6 May 1918, he was chief of headquarters of the rear. He then became chief of security of the occupied areas until 22 May 1918. On 28 November 1918, Walden became minister of war and held this position until 15 August 1919. Walden was then promoted to commander in chief of the Finnish army and the [[Suojeluskunta|Civil Guard]] (27 November 1918 - 30 December 1918). Walden and general of the White army [[Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim]] developed a close working relationship that continued throughout the inter war period (head of Finnish Red Cross in the 20th century) and during the Winter War and Continuation War.
==Finnish paper industry== After leaving the army, Walden sought a career in business. He moved to [[Saint Petersburg]], the capital of the [[Russian Empire]], and after few years founded a sales agency for Finnish paper. As a steadfast patriot, Walden also became a prominent figure in the large Finnish community of Saint Petersburg. From 1906 to 1946, Walden worked in the [[Pulp and paper industry|paper industry]]. He worked to consolidate the Finnish paper industry. He founded ''[[:fi:Yhtyneet Paperitehtaat|Yhtyneet Paperitehtaat Oy]]'' ([[UPM (company)|United Paper Mills Ltd]]) and was the first president of "Finpap", a Finnish paper sales association.
==Winter War== During the Finnish-Soviet [[Winter War]], Walden was recalled to active service. From 3 December 1939 to 27 March 1940, he was a member of the war cabinet. On 27 March 1940 he became [[Minister of Defence (Finland)|Minister of Defence]] and continued in this role till 27 November 1944.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://valtioneuvosto.fi/tietoa/historiaa/hallitukset-ja-ministerit/raportti/-/r/v9l/11 |title=Council of State - Ministers of Defence|publisher=Valtioneuvosto.fi |accessdate=30 December 2017 }}</ref> Walden was able to maintain important diplomatic relationships with [[Sweden]] and the [[United States]]. Walden represented Finland at the [[Treaty of Tartu (Russian–Finnish)|Treaty of Tartu]] of 1920, the [[Moscow Peace Treaty (1940)]], and the [[Paris Peace Treaty|Armistice treaty of Moscow (1944)]].
After the Civil war and during the 1930s there was general distrust of the labour movement and the [[Spirit of the Winter War|patriotism of the Finnish worker]]. In Winter War this proved unfounded and the nation was united. Industrial leader Walden and [[Väinö Tanner]] ([[Social Democrat]] leader and Finnish foreign minister) had developed mutual respect and worked well together. In the so-called [[Betrothal of January]] 1940, Finland's industry associations acknowledged the trade unions as negotiation partners regarding labour issues.
== Civilian and military decorations == In 1919, Walden became Commander of the [[Order of the White Rose]]. Later, he received the Grand Cross of the order. For his services during and after the [[Finnish Civil War]] he was awarded the [[Order of the Cross of Liberty|Grand Cross of Liberty]]. He was also awarded the [[Iron Cross]] (1918). During the 1920s, Walden became a knight of the [[Order of the Polar Star]] (Sweden). In 1928, Walden received the Danish Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Dannebrog]] personally from King [[Christian X]]. During his service as minister of defence, Walden received several decorations including the Swedish [[Order of the Sword]], the German [[Order of the German Eagle]] and [[Iron Cross]] (1939) 1st and 2nd class, the Hungarian Grand Cross of Order of Merit, and the Romanian Grand Cross of [[Steaua României|Order of the Star]]. On 2 December 1944 he received the [[Mannerheim Cross]] of the [[Order of the Cross of Liberty]] for his services to the country.

[[Image:Salvatore Grimaldi in Dec 2013.jpg|upright|thumb | Salvatore Grimaldi in 2013]] '''Salvatore Grimaldi'''{{Needs IPA|Swedish}} ({{IPA-it|salvaˈtoːre ɡriˈmaldi|lang}}; born 25 May 1945) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] entrepreneur and speaker. He is the chairman of Företagarna and the CEO of [[Grimaldi Industri|Grimaldi Industri AB]].<ref name="kristoffertörnmalm">{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/cykelkungen-har-sitt-italien-i-hjartat|title="Cykelkungen" har sitt Italien i hjärtat|author=Kristoffer Törnmalm|work=SvD.se}}</ref>
==Early life== Salvatore Grimaldi was born in [[Taranto]], [[Italy]]. He migrated from Italy to [[Västerås]], Sweden with his parents in the early 1950s.<ref name="kristoffertörnmalm"/> His mother came to Sweden to visit her brothers, who had found work at a company called Asea. She found Sweden to be such a beautiful country that she decided to stay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dn.se/livsstil/reportage/salvatore-grimaldi-mor-hade-sju-syskon-som-kom-hit-vi-skapade-ett-little-italy-i-vasteras/|title=Salvatore Grimaldi: Mor hade sju syskon som kom hit – vi skapade ett Little Italy i Västerås.|work=DN.SE|accessdate=18 October 2015}}</ref>
==Career== After working at [[Volvo]], Grimaldi founded a grind mill in his own garage in [[Köping]] in 1970. In 1982, he started acquiring companies, including [[Bianchi Bicycles|Bianchi]], [[Monark]], [[Crescent]] and [[Stiga]]. He then restructured these companies and sold off portions of the companies that did not contribute to his business objectives. Grimaldi ultimately acquired substantial wealth from these transactions.<ref name="kristoffertörnmalm"/>
==Personal life== [[image:Diplomatstaden 2008 Dipl 2.jpg|thumb|Villa Geber, Grimaldi's home since 2001]] In 2001, Grimaldi received attention from local media when he bought [[Villa Geber]] in Diplomatstaden, Stockholm for around 70 million (SEK).<ref name="Villa Geber">[http://www.dagensps.se/article.aspx?articleID=38901&categID=96 Dagensps Salvatore Grimaldi] dagensps.se Retrieved 14 October 2015 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612000019/http://www.dagensps.se/article.aspx?articleID=38901&categID=96 |date=12 June 2008 }}</ref> At the time, Villa Geber was one of the most expensive private homes in Sweden.<ref name = "Villa Geber"/> On July 1, 2002, he presented an episode of the [[Sveriges Radio]] show ''[[Sommar i P1]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/avsnitt/389621?programid=2071|title=Salvatore Grimaldi 2002|author=Sveriges Radio|work=sverigesradio.se}}</ref> Grimaldi was the chairman of Sweden's largest business owners organisation Företagarna between 2004 and 2006. He is also the chairman of Italienska Handelskammaren, Accademia Italiana della Cucina, Direct Försäkringsmäklarna Västerås.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mdh.se/salvatore-grimaldi-talar-pa-mdh-1.56664|title=Salvatore Grimaldi talar på MDH|work=mdh.se}}</ref> In 2004, Grimaldi was awarded an Honorary Doctorate at Mälardalens College.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mdh.se/hogskolan/fakta/mdh-s-hedersdoktorer-1.1654?l=sv_SE|title=MDH:s hedersdoktorer|work=mdh.se|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819205358/http://www.mdh.se/hogskolan/fakta/mdh-s-hedersdoktorer-1.1654?l=sv_SE|archivedate=2014-08-19|df=}}</ref> In 1988, he was awarded the Royal Patriotic Society's Business Medal for his entrepreneurship and his work contributing to important progress of Swedish businesses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.herbertfelixinstitutet.se/en/node/295|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304082903/http://www.herbertfelixinstitutet.se/en/node/295|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-03-04|title=Salvatore Grimaldi|work=herbertfelixinstitutet.se}}</ref> In 2011, Network Europe named Grimaldi "[t]he richest immigrant in Sweden", noting that his assets were valued at 1.6 billion [[Swedish krona|Swedish kronor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://networkeurope.radio.cz/feature/the-richest-immigrant-in-sweden|title=The richest immigrant in Sweden|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2015}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Sam Hammam | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Samir Georges Nassib Hammam | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1947|7|17|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Sam Hammam|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SAM+HAMMAM.-a0119885514|publisher=South Wales Echo|accessdate=7 January 2015|date=28 July 2004}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Shweir]], [[Lebanon]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|df=yes|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = Lebanese | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = Football club chairman }} '''Samir "Sam" Hammam''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: سمير همام) is a Lebanese businessman, well known for his high-profile involvement in British [[association football|football]] clubs, and presently holding a life presidency at [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-23439428.stm "Sam Hammam urges Cardiff FC fans to back Vincent Tan"][[BBC]]Retrieved on 17 August 2013,</ref>
==Wimbledon== Originally moving to the area due to being a keen [[tennis]] fan, Hammam became involved in football by buying £40,000 worth of shares at [[Non-League football|non-league]] [[Wimbledon F.C.]] in two years,<ref>[http://football.guardian.co.uk/FA_Cup/Story/0,,629335,00.html "The Guardian: Still crazy"]</ref> eventually taking full control of the club in 1977.<ref name=inside>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sport/football/656552.stm|title=Hammam sells Wimbledon stake|date=25 February 2000|accessdate=5 January 2015|work=BBC}}</ref>
Under Hammam, Wimbledon achieved four promotions in nine years, becoming a [[Football League First Division]] club in 1986 and winning the [[FA Cup]] in [[1987–88 FA Cup|1988]].
In 1990, before Wimbledon had moved out of their [[Plough Lane]] ground to groundshare at [[Selhurst Park]] with local rivals [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], Hammam bought out a covenant held on the ground by the [[London Borough of Merton|Council]] that required it to be retained for sporting use.<ref>[http://www.wisa.org.uk/cgi/l/articles/index.cgi?action=show&id=523 "WISA article on lifting of Plough Lane covenant"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426070543/http://www.wisa.org.uk/cgi/l/articles/index.cgi?action=show&id=523 |date=26 April 2012 }} Retrieved on 23 December 2011.</ref> During the 1990s, Hammam failed in an attempt to relocate the club to [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/championship/3010879/Inside-Sport-Hammam-cast-in-villains-role-as-Dons-seek-happy-ending.html|title=Inside Sport: Hammam cast in villain's role as Dons seek happy ending|date=16 August 2001|accessdate=5 January 2015|work=The Telegraph}}</ref>
In 1997, Hammam sold 80% of his shares in Wimbledon to [[Bjørn Rune Gjelsten]] and [[Kjell Inge Røkke]]. He sold the remaining 20% to Gjelsten and Røkke in February 2000, three months before the club's relegation from the [[Premier League]].<ref name=inside/> In 2004, Wimbledon F.C. was relocated to [[Milton Keynes]] and rebranded as the [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|MK Dons]], with the newly formed [[AFC Wimbledon]] often considered the successor club to the original Wimbledon.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/9223993.stm|title=AFC Wimbledon chase FA Cup history against Stevenage |date=25 November 2010|accessdate=5 January 2014|work=BBC}}</ref>
==Cardiff City== Hammam purchased control of Cardiff City F.C. at the end of 2000, where he picked up where he left off with Wimbledon. After taking over at Cardiff, Hammam controversially pledged to get the entire Welsh nation to support Cardiff by renaming the club ''"The Cardiff Celts"'' and changing the club colours to green, red and white.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/wales/846497.stm BBC Wales: Hammam: 'I will die for Cardiff Celts']</ref><sup>,</sup><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/wales/863572.stm BBC Wales: Fans are Hammam's big worry]</ref>
At Cardiff he became a [[cult following|cult]]-hero with fans for taking part in their head-patting '[[The Ayatollah (football celebration)|do the Ayatollah]]' chant. One such game saw him performing the celebration during an infamous 2–1 home win in the [[FA Cup]] against then-[[Premier League]] side [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in 2002. This, along with other aspects of his behaviour during the match, was blamed for contributing to the subsequent violence between Leeds and Cardiff fans at the end of the match.<ref>[http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/sport/Cardiff-supremo-rejects-mayhem-claims.2292427.jp "Cardiff supremo rejects mayham claims"], ''[[The Scotsman]]'' Retrieved on 6 December 2008</ref>
After failing to get the new stadium plans agreed by [[Cardiff Council]] due to concerns over financial security in 2006, Hammam agreed to a takeover by a consortium led by new chairman [[Peter Ridsdale]] and including local businessman Paul Guy. In March 2008, Cardiff City began a court case against financial backers Langston over the repayment of a loan believed to be worth around £31 million. During the hearing the barrister representing the club named Sam Hammam as the man they believe to be behind the company.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/7290681.stm "Hammam named in Cardiff loan case"] [[BBC]] Retrieved on 14 March 2008,</ref> No settlement was reached in the case.
In July 2013, following Cardiff City's promotion to the Premier League, it emerged that Malaysian businessman [[Vincent Tan]], who had taken effective control of the club in 2010, was in advanced talks with Hammam – confirmed as Langston's spokesman – about repayment of the loan, then thought to be around £24 million.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-23362625.stm "Vincent Tan: Cardiff City could be debt-free in 'days'"] [[BBC]] Retrieved on 17 August 2013,</ref> Four days later, on 18 July 2013, Tan announced that an "amicable resolution" had been reached between Cardiff City and Langston over the debt issue, with Sam Hammam becoming a life president of the club.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23413324.stm "Cardiff City: Tan & Langston reach "amicable resolution""]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[BBC]] Retrieved on 17 August 2013,</ref> Hammam confirmed this in an interview with the [[BBC]] on 24 July, requesting that fans of the club back the Malaysian owner.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-23439428.stm "Sam Hammam urges Cardiff FC fans to back Vincent Tan"][[BBC]] Retrieved on 17 August 2013,</ref>
==Controversy== Hammam has achieved a level of notoriety in English football for his unusual antics at matches, frequently walking around the pitchside during games, and his eccentric methods of publicising himself and his players. On at least one occasion he made a player eat sheep's testicles prior to signing with Cardiff City.<ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/1411563.stm BBC Sport:Prior moves to Cardiff 28 June 2001</ref>

{{spanish name|Gómez|Giraldo}} {{notability|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox president |name = Tulio Gómez |image = |imagesize = |caption = |order = 21st |office = President of América de Cali |term_start = 10 May 2016 |term_end = 16 May 2018 |predecessor = Oreste Sangiovanni |successor = [[Ricardo Pérez]] |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Manizales]], [[Caldas Department|Caldas]], Colombia |birthname = Tulio Alberto Gómez Giraldo |spouse = {{Marriage|Myriam Giraldo|1987}} |children = 2 |alma_mater = |profession = [[Businessperson|Business Person]] |residence = |nationality = Colombia |party = |religion = |vicepresident = |notable prizes = |signature = |website = |footnotes = |box_width = }} '''Tulio Alberto Gómez Giraldo''' (Manizales, Colombia), is a [[businessperson|business person]] and the 21st President and biggest shareholder of the Colombian football club [[América de Cali]]. He's the founder and owner of supermarket chains ''Superinter''.
== Career == He founded supermarkets Supeinter in the city of [[Cali]], in 1990.<ref>{{Cita web|url=http://www.elpais.com.co/deportes/america-de-cali-los-genes-de-don-tulio.html|title=América de Cali: los genes de don Tulio|access-date=4 December 2016|website=elpais.com.co|language=es}}</ref>
In 2014 he bought a few shares in the [[America de Cali]] on advice from his wife, but realizing that he did not have so many rights, he bought more and kept 53% of the shares of the club that allowed him to make all the decisions.<ref>{{Cita web|url=https://www.radionacional.co/noticia/actualidad/presidente-del-america-paso-vender-ganado-alimentos-a-negociar-futbol-0|title=La historia de Tulio Gómez, presidente del América de Cali|access-date=20 September 2016|website=radionacional.co|language=es}}</ref> On May 10 of 2016 he became the new Chairman of America de Cali.<ref>{{Cita web|url=https://colombia.as.com/colombia/2016/05/05/futbol/1462467970_048039.html|title=Tulio Gómez, el nuevo mandamás del América de Cali|access-date=5 May 2016|website=colombia.as.com|language=es}}</ref>
On November 27, 2016, Tulio Gómez was one of the architect men in the rise of América de Cali to the [[Categoría Primera A]] of Colombian football, together with the team's coach that year [[Hernán Torres]].<ref>{{Cita web|url=https://www.elespectador.com/deportes/futbolcolombiano/tulio-gomez-el-artifice-del-ascenso-articulo-667790|title=Tulio Gómez, el artífice del ascenso|access-date=27 November 2016|website=elespectador.com|language=es}}</ref>
On May 16, 2018, Tulio Gómez announced his retirement as President of the institution after bad management and an irregular campaign in the [[2018 Categoría Primera A season|2018 Liga Águila]], although declared that it would continue being the owner of the team.<ref>{{Cita web|url=http://www.elpais.com.co/america-de-cali/a-partir-de-hoy-me-hago-a-un-lado-de-la-presidencia-de-tulio-gomez.html|title=Tulio Gómez renuncia a la Presidencia del América de Cali|date=16 May 2018|website=elpais.com.co|language=es}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox university |name= UQ Business School |image= UQ Business School Logo.png |image_size= 220px |established= 1972 |type= |dean= Professor Julie Cogin<ref>https://www.business.uq.edu.au/staff/julie-cogin</ref> |city= [[Brisbane]] |state = [[Queensland]] |country= [[Australia]] |coor = {{coord|-27.4947|153.0142|type:edu_region:AU-QLD|display=inline,title}} |students= 7,500+ |faculty= 150+ |affiliations= [[University of Queensland]], [[Group of Eight (Australian universities)|Group of Eight]], [[Universitas 21]], [[ASAIHL]] |website= {{URL|http://www.business.uq.edu.au/}} }}
The '''University of Queensland Business School''' is the [[business school]] of the [[University of Queensland]], located in Brisbane, Australia. There are seven areas of research expertise across UQ Business School: Accounting, Business Information Systems, Finance, Management, Marketing, Strategy and Tourism.
The school began teaching its [[MBA]] program in 1972, the very first to be offered in [[Queensland]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} It became the first business school in Australia to meet the standards of the accrediting bodies - the US-based [[AACSB]] International<ref>https://datadirect.aacsb.edu/public/profiles/profile.cfm?runReport=1&unitid=54855&userType=All</ref> and Europe’s [[EQUIS]].<ref>http://www.efmd.org/accreditation-main/equis/accredited-schools</ref>
''[[The Economist]]'' has ranked the UQ Business School 10th in the world in its 2016 Global Business School Rankings and 1st in the Asia-Pacific.<ref>http://www.economist.com/whichmba/full-time-mba-ranking</ref> The 2013 ''[[The Australian Financial Review|Australian Financial Review]]'' BOSS MBA Rankings ranked the school first in Australia.<ref>http://www.afr.com/p/national/education/queensland_beats_melbourne_to_offer_qqYlQG2uOqyKsZ0owMygBL</ref>
In addition, along with Faculty of Business, Economics & Law, UQ Business School collaborates with [[Mahidol University International College]] and [[The Chinese University of Hong Kong]] to introduce [https://bel.uq.edu.au/bihtm-exchange-opportunity-thailand-and-hong-kong Asia-Pacific Hospitality Management Program], exclusively available to its Bachelor of International and Tourism Management students. <ref>https://bel.uq.edu.au/bihtm-exchange-opportunity-thailand-and-hong-kong</ref>
==History== UQ Business School’s origins date back to 1926 when the University of Queensland first began to offer accounting degrees. The Department of Accountancy was set up in 1961, and later became the School of Commerce. Management education began in 1972, when the first [[MBA]] students enrolled.
The school was renamed the Department of Business Administration and later became School of Management in 1984.<ref>https://www.business.uq.edu.au/about</ref>
UQ Business School was formed in 2002 with the merger of the Schools of Commerce and Management, and two years later it expanded further when it merged with the Technology and Innovation Management Centre (TIMC).<ref>https://www.business.uq.edu.au/about</ref>
UQ Business School was the first business school in Australia to gain dual accreditation from AACSB International and EQUIS - the most prestigious standards a business school can achieve.<ref>https://www.business.uq.edu.au/about</ref>
== Campuses == UQ Business School operates over two sites. Most of the school’s staff are located at the St Lucia campus, a 114-acre site located seven miles from the centre of Brisbane within a bend in the [[Brisbane River]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
UQ Business School Downtown (UQBS Downtown) is situated in Brisbane’s central business district and is home to the school’s Corporate Education and MBA programs. It opened in 2004. This learning and conference centre won the Queensland Architecture Award (Interiors) in 2005.<ref>[http://www.architecture.com.au/i-cms?page=6797 Australian Institute of Architects]</ref>
==Rankings and awards== * 1st ranked MBA program in Asia-Pacific in The Economist 2016 Full-time MBA ranking<ref>http://www.economist.com/whichmba/full-time-mba-ranking</ref> * 10th ranked MBA program in the world in The Economist 2016 Full-time MBA ranking<ref>http://www.economist.com/whichmba/full-time-mba-ranking</ref> * 1st/17 best business school in Australia in the Financial Review Boss 2015 MBA ranking<ref>http://www.afr.com/p/boss/boss_mba_ranking_the_table_3ADFi8K8AnTSJEi6O9HvyH</ref> * [[GMAA]] Five Star rating of MBA program for the ninth consecutive year<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gmaa.com.au/star-rating |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213051010/http://www.gmaa.com.au/star-rating/ |archivedate=13 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * The Australian Research Council’s ERA (The Excellence in Research for Australia) rates UQ Business School’s research above or well above world standard in all categories (banking, finance, investment, business and management scoring 5 stars)<ref>http://www.business.uq.edu.au/news/uq_business_school_top_researchers_in_the_state_2011_02_01</ref> * 47th/50 best business school in the world in the [[Financial Times]] executive education open 2011 ranking<ref>[http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/executive-education-open-2011 The Financial Times Executive education open 2011]</ref> * Martie-Louise Verreynne, Stewart Gow and Clint Ramsay, awarded by the Australian Teaching and Learning Council(ATLC)<ref>http://blog.studylink.com/2010/10/uq-business-school-offers-practical-experience/</ref>
==Programs== Degree offerings include [[undergraduate]], [[postgraduate]] coursework and postgraduate research programs in business, commerce, and management. [[Executive education]] programs address a wide range of contemporary business issues.
===Undergraduate programs=== * [[Bachelor of Business Management]] (BBusMan) * [[Bachelor of Commerce]] (BCom) * Bachelor of International Hotel and Tourism Management (BIHTM) * Bachelor of Advanced Business (Honours) (BAdvBusH)
===Postgraduate programs=== * [[Bachelor of Commerce#Honours Bachelor of Commerce|Honours program]] * [[Master of Commerce]] (MCom): covers competencies in accounting, finance, information systems and [[e-commerce]]. * Master of Project Management (MPM): allows to learn more about the discipline of organizing and managing resources. * Master of Property Studies (MPropertySt): covers the knowledge and understanding of the business environment, real estate and development, and key property sectors. * Master of Technology and Innovation Management (MTIM): covers the knowledge and skills to manage innovation and technology in both public and private sector organisations. * Master of Global Management: two years, two degrees in two world-class universities. * [[Master of Business]] (MBus): allows students to gain specialist knowledge and qualifications for middle/senior management. * [[Master of Business Administration]] (MBA) * [[PhD]]
===Executive Education programs and courses=== The University of Queensland Business School Executive Education is part of UQ Business School and the University of Queensland. It offers [[executive education]] courses for individuals and organisations in key business arenas. * Advanced Presentation Skills * Design Thinking for Business * Designing Strategy for Results * Enhanced Customer Experience Strategy * Finance for Non-Finance Managers * Innovation Leadership * Leadership Styles and Practice * Leadership for Executive Women * Leadership for Senior Executive Women * Leading People and Teams * Operations Design * Optimising Influence in Negotiation * Strategic Marketing * Sun Tzu's Art of War * Women in Clinical Leadership * Graduate Certificate in Executive Leadership * Medical Leadership Program
